flow.descriptionCdata:
1b6596e2-2517-44d4-a406-af25205cc914.1d017b0f-fe13-46cd-9404-4f4866427787.description=
Checks to see if a string matches another string using a specific rule. Input toMatch is the actual string to check to see if it matches the matchTo expression.

Inputs\:
    matchType - The type of match to perform.
Valid values\: Exact Match, Contains, Contains Once, Does Not Contain, Match All Words, Match No Words, Regex
Default value\: Exact Match
    toMatch - The string to check if matches another string.
    matchTo - The string to match against. 
Examples\: If the matchType is RegEx, the input matchTo is the regular expression like \: ^-?\d+(([\.,]\d+)?)+$. 
    ignoreCase - Boolean value for whether or not to ignore case during match.
Valid values\: False, True
Default value\: False

Responses\:
    success - The String matched.
    failure - The string did not match, or something went wrong.
1b6596e2-2517-44d4-a406-af25205cc914.250c6675-4373-4203-9d2a-826052b2b1b9.callout=Resets domain user password. 1b6596e2-2517-44d4-a406-af25205cc914.377c9186-5e50-404d-8cb7-f4eadfc9892f.callout=This flow resets the password of a Windows user, either locally or inside a domain. The action ends with a notification. 1b6596e2-2517-44d4-a406-af25205cc914.3e9600e0-9d94-4a9a-a87d-4d21243175df.description=
This utility flow is used to determine whether a domain user was provided. It investigates if either of the two inputs has indicated the presence of a domain..

Inputs\:
    targetedUsername - The username to search in.
    domain - The domain to inspect.

Responses\:
    Is Domain User - The flow identified the presence of a domain in one of the two inputs.
    Is Not Domai User - The flow did not detect any domain inside the inputs.
1b6596e2-2517-44d4-a406-af25205cc914.43d704ed-cc5b-42a1-98bb-762c4d8642f6.callout=Checks whether user is local user or domain user. 1b6596e2-2517-44d4-a406-af25205cc914.5b33bc57-8e8b-46ef-80e0-d52317b07bc5.description=
Generates a random password.

Inputs\:
passwordLength - the required length of the password
numberOfNonAlphanumericCharacters - the minimum number of non alphanumeric numbers

Responses\:
success - password generated
failure - failed to generate password

Extra Results\:
password - the generated password

NOTE\:
If passwordLength or numberOfNonAlphanumericCharacters are less than 0 or if numberOfNonAlphanumericCharacters is greater than passwordLength  the operation will succeed  and will return an empty password.
1b6596e2-2517-44d4-a406-af25205cc914.67280ad8-c30d-4589-ae82-e250383dbcf4.prompt=Use Random Password? 1b6596e2-2517-44d4-a406-af25205cc914.82dc1ec2-c661-4e59-960a-13240c2ff5e3.callout=Checks whether to generate a random password or not. 1b6596e2-2517-44d4-a406-af25205cc914.89ae352c-e3c6-4e5a-9ae4-b0de751fffba.callout=Notifies user if password was reset. 1b6596e2-2517-44d4-a406-af25205cc914.9be35958-da69-41f3-b9a2-19ddbc4ead89.callout=Resets local user password. 1b6596e2-2517-44d4-a406-af25205cc914.9bf600d6-8bb3-43e5-a5ee-34a55b201454.callout=Generates a random password. 1b6596e2-2517-44d4-a406-af25205cc914.description=
Changes the password of windows user and notifies. This can be used to change the password either for a local windows user or a domain user. For domain users, after changing the password the user is forced to change his password again at first log in.
The flow allows the user to enter the new password manually or to let the flow generate a random one. If the flow randomly generates the new password, it will try three times to generate the password according to the password policies from the target machine. If it fails three times consecutively to generate a valid password, the flow will fail, asking the user to manually enter a password that matches the password policies.

Inputs\:
    host - If you want to change the password of a local user, this should be the target windows machine on which the local user exists. If you want to change the password of a domain user, this should be the domain controller that manages the accounts.
    adminUsername - The user with administrator privileges on the host. If using a domain controller, the full username can be specified, including the domain.
Example\: Administrator, userWitAdimPriviledges@domain, domain\userWithAdminPriviledges
    adminPassword - The password of the user with administrator privileges.
    domain - The domain of the user. If you want to change the password of a domain user and did not include the domain in the adminUsername you have to set it here.
    targetedUsername - The user for which the password has to be changed. For Active Directory users this should be the sAMAccountName.
    useRandomPassword - Specifies if the password will be randomly generated, or will be provided as input.
Valid Values\: true, false
Default Value\: true
    randomPasswordLength - If randomPassword is true, this input specifies the length of the password to be generated.
Default Value\: 8
    newPassword - The new password for the specified user. This needs to be provided only if randmPassword is set to false.	   
    emailTo - The destination of the notification (email address). 
    emailServer - The email server to send the notification through.
    emailFrom - The originator of the message (email "from" address).
    emailPort - The port on which smtp service is listening.
Default Value\: 25
	
Responses\:
    success - The flow completed successfully and the password has been changed.
    failure - The flow has failed to change the password.
1b6596e2-2517-44d4-a406-af25205cc914.ef9b54dd-86d7-4100-880b-1c7b8e7d595d.description=
Runs a command, allowing you to specify whether it runs locally (no port to be specified), via SSH, Global Shell, ROSH, Telnet, or RSH.

Inputs\:
    host - The host name or IP address.
    port - The port number used to connect to the host.
    username - The user name used to connect.
    password - The password associated with the  input. If using a private key file, this is the passphrase for the file.
    protocol - The protocol used to run the command. 
Examples\: SSH, ROSH, GlobalShell, Telnet, RSH, REXEC, local, WMI, NASConnectTelnet, HPOM
    timeout - The time to wait for the command to complete (in milliseconds). Increase this value if you are getting incomplete output results or a timeout.
Default value\: 90000
    command - The command to run.
    arguments - The arguments to pass to the command.
    environment - Specifies the environment variables and values that need to be defined when running the command.
    startDir - The path to the starting directory.
    pty - Specifies whether to use pty (used by SSH, GlobalShell)
Valid values\: true, false
    privateKeyFile - The path to the private key file, relative to ICONCLUDE_HOME on the RAS host (used by SSH, GlobalShell).
    sasHost - The host on which to run the ROSH command.
    sasHostUsername - The user name used to run the ROSH command on .
    usernamePrompt - The prompt message for the user name. Used by the Telnet protocol. When used by the NASConnectTelnet protocol, the default value is 'NAS Login\:'.
    passwordPrompt - The prompt message for the password associated with the < usernamePrompt > input. Used by the Telnet protocol.  When used by the 'NASConnectTelnet' protocol, the default value is 'Password\:'
    outputPath - The network accessible path where to store the temporary files. If you do not specify this input, it points to '\\host\admin$\temp\'. If this path is not accessible, change it to use another share to which the host local system account has write access. By default, the path needs to be changed on Windows 2000 systems.
    nasDevice - The NAS device on which to run the command when using the 'NASConnect' protocol.
    nasDeviceConsoleMode - The NAS device console mode used to run the command scripts running the command on the specified NAS device. If you leave this input empty, command scripts are not used, and the connections to the NAS device and the command are issued directly in the console. This is not recommended. Due to error handling capabilities limitation, the result might be a success even if the command failed to run. You can find the values for this input in the NAS web interface, as a drop-down list when creating a new command script (for example, Cisco IOS enable).
    hpomNode - The node on which to run the command.
    hpomProtocol - The protocol used to communicate with HPOM (HTTP or HTTPS).
    characterSet - The name of the character set used for stream encoding and decoding between the RAS and target machine.
Default value\: UTF-8 (used by SSH, GlobalShell, Telnet, RSH, REXEC)
Examples\: SJIS,EUC-JP, UTF-8

Results\:
    returnResult - This is the primary output. Used to determine the operation response, specifying whether the operation is successful or not.
    stdOut - The standard output (STDOUT) of the command.
    stdErr - The standard error (STDERR) of the command.

Responses\:
    success - The operation completed as stated in the description.
    failure - The operation completed unsuccessfully.

Notes\:
Telnet protocol - Since telnet is shell protocol, not a remote execution protocol, the response is always  successful if the command is ran in the remote shell.  The return code of the specified command cannot be determined in this protocol.  If you must use the telnet protocol with this operation, make sure to check the command results. Consider using the SSH or REXEC protocol instead.
flow.name: Reset User Password

scriptlet.name: Step Use Random Password? in Flow Reset User Password (1d017b0f-fe13-46cd-9404-4f4866427787)
Step Reset Local User Password in Flow Reset User Password (ef9b54dd-86d7-4100-880b-1c7b8e7d595d)
default
